title: 112_hr6517
content:
The "STEM Network Act" authorizes grants for STEM programs. The STEM Network Act authorizes grants for eligible networks to expand STEM education, defined as State-based organizations aiming to improve STEM achievement in schools, especially those with low-income and rural students. Eligible networks include various stakeholders like educators, industry leaders, and parents. The STEM Network Act requires eligible networks to submit an application for a grant, including non-Federal matching funds of at least 30 percent. The funds can be used for various purposes outlined in the act. Eligible networks receiving grants under the STEM Network Act must use the funds for testing, sharing, and scaling up STEM education research and programs, identifying strengths and weaknesses in State STEM efforts, and assisting in implementing common content standards for grades prekindergarten through 12. The Common Core State Standards Initiative focuses on international standards, 21st-century skills, English language learners, and special education students. It also aims to increase scientific literacy from prekindergarten to grade 12. Additionally, it supports the development of STEM assessments and teacher programs emphasizing STEM content. Professional development for in-service STEM teachers is also promoted. Developing STEM career pathways, workforce education, and extended learning times to enhance STEM education inside and outside the classroom. SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND REPORT.

Eligible networks receiving grants must conduct independent evaluations of their effectiveness in STEM teaching and learning activities and submit reports to the Secretary. SEC. 6 prohibits the Secretary from endorsing any STEM curriculum for schools and from requiring specific STEM programs. SEC. 7 limits grants to $20,000,000 per fiscal year. SEC. 8 provides definitions. In this Act, key terms such as "elementary school", "local educational agency", "secondary school", "high concentration of low-income students", "institution of higher education", "Secretary", and "State" are defined. The term "STEM" refers to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics in the context of Puerto Rico, Guam, the Commonwealth of Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, and the United States Virgin Islands.
